Use & to plot multiple words as separate: Use & to plot multiple words as separate lines
Use + to combine multiple words into one: Use + to combine multiple words into one line
Add a new tab to compare different corpo: Add a new tab to compare different corpora or resolutions
Start date warning: Start date ({{startDate}}) is before the recommended period start ({{periodStart}}) for {{corpusName}}
End date warning: End date ({{endDate}}) is after the recommended period end ({{periodEnd}}) for {{corpusName}}
Moving Average Help: Moving Average calculates the average value over a sliding window of data points. For each point, it looks at neighboring points within the window size and computes their mean. This reduces noise and reveals trends in the data.
Loess Smoothing Help: Loess (Locally Estimated Scatterplot Smoothing) fits multiple local regression models to subsets of the data. It creates a smooth curve that follows the data patterns more closely than a moving average, especially for non-linear trends.
We do not handle the context (yet?) for: We do not handle the context (yet?) for this corpus
le_monde_warning: NB: Here, we rely on Le Monde search engine, which sometimes works in mysterious ways.
long_query_warning: This query can take a while. Please be patient. If it times out, please retry to get the partial results (cached).
By word in the same article: By word in the same article
Rescale help: Normalizes curves so they all start at the same point (index 100).
Ratio help: Plots the ratio between the frequencies of two terms (e.g., A / B).
Difference help: Plots the difference between the frequencies of two terms (e.g., A - B).
Loess Smoothing help: Smoothes curves to reveal general trends by reducing noise.
Show Confidence Interval help: Displays the statistical margin of error around the curves.
Show Total Barplot help: Adds a bar chart showing the total number of occurrences for each term.
stopwords_help: Number of frequent words to exclude.
Search mode ngram description: Fraction of all syntagms that are this syntagm.
Search mode document description: Fraction of documents that feature this syntagm at least once.
Search mode cooccurrence description: Fraction of documents that have two syntagms at proximity.
Search mode joker description: Search for what follows most often this syntagm.
Search mode nearby description: Search for the words that are most often around this syntagm.
Search mode associated article descripti: Search for words that appear in the same article as this syntagm.
Search mode article description: Fraction of articles that feature this syntagm at least once.
Search mode cooccurrence article descrip: Fraction of articles that feature two syntagms at proximity.
Long query warning: Your query has {{count}} words, but the maximum for {{corpusName}} is {{max}}.
Long query warning lemonde restricted: For Le Monde corpus and this search mode, the maximum number of words is 1.
Extend Y-scale to 0 help: Forces the Y-axis to start at 0.
Low data warning: Since this word is rare ({{count}} occurrences), we humbly suggest visualizing the results with this bar chart. You can switch back to the line chart by changing the option, but it will likely look like nothing.
Corpus bundle help: Sum frequencies across corpora for the same word.
Base 100 help: Normalizes all curves so that they equal 1 in the specified year.
about_benoit: is a social science researcher, currently a postdoc at the London School of Economics.
about_benjamin: Benjamin Azoulay is a senior civil servant and maritime affairs administrator. He is currently seconded as a senior data scientist at the Ministry of Finance.
about_project_p1: Gallicagram is a lockdown project that got out of hand. In 2021, Benjamin showed Benoît, a vague acquaintance, a snippet of code he wrote to plot (ugly) frequency curves of phrases in the French National Library's corpora. Benoît, whose coding skills were barely any better back then, exclaimed that it would be a brilliant idea to wrap this code in a Shiny app so that a computer-illiterate historian could plot curves too. Fast forward 5 years and a few thousand hours of work later, Benjamin and Benoît are now friends and slightly less incompetent. The project has expanded significantly, comprising several facets:
about_project_li1: Corpora that we scrape, a list of which you can find
about_project_li2_1: Large databases tallying the frequency of words and phrases in these corpora. Unlike the corpora themselves, these databases are copyright-free and freely accessible via an open API, documented
about_project_li2_2: . These databases are stored in sqlite3 format on a server graciously provided by ENS Paris-Saclay.
about_project_li3_1: A graphical user interface to explore these databases, generate plots, and export them. The current GUI is coded in React and hosted on Vercel. Its source code is available
about_project_li4: Research projects using our corpora, such as
about_ack_p1: First and foremost to ENS Paris-Saclay and Frédéric Lebaron for their hosting and unwavering support.
about_ack_p2: Thanks also to the Maison des Sciences de l'Homme and Sébastien Oliveau, who provided us with a second server for scraping and "cold" data storage.
about_ack_p3: Thanks to Vincent Bagilet and Will Gleason, who respectively helped us to improve the API and Gallica's context.
about_ack_p4: Thanks to the many researchers who help us spread the word about this tool and improve it with their ideas and technical advice. Off the top of our heads, a few names: Olivier Ritz, Baptiste Coulmont, Guillaume Plique, Benjamin Ooghe-Tabanou.
